Award.AwardTitle: Deaf Learners' Lexical Acquisition of English Verbs and Their Component Properties

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A verb plays a central role in establishing the form and meaning of a sentence because every verb, along with its meaning, has properties that determine what other structures can occur with it in a sentence and how the whole sentence functions in communicating events. For example, specific properties of the English verbs 'sink' and 'build' determine the acceptability of the sentences "The enemy sank the ship" and "The enemy built the ship," as well as the acceptability of "The ship sank" but the unacceptability of "The ship built." Hearing native speakers naturally acquire the requisite lexical knowledge of English verbs that determines the admissible forms and functions of sentences. However, acquisition of spoken-language knowledge under exceptional circumstances, as with deaf persons, can be compromised because deaf learners have (variably) restricted auditory access to input from the spoken language. Under these circumstances, lower levels of proficiency in the spoken language often result, with potentially serious negative consequences for educational and career success.

To gain a deeper understanding of deaf learners' lexical acquisition of English verbs, this research project undertakes a comprehensive investigation of deaf college students' knowledge of isolatable lexical properties of verbs using sentence acceptability rating scale tasks. It examines deaf learners' verb knowledge as it pertains to transitivity and intransitivity, verb-determined sentence structure, the semantic roles of verbs' subjects and objects, meaning classes of verbs, and the roles verbs play in communicating events such as actions, activities, and accomplishments. Deaf learners' English verb knowledge within and across these lexical domains is compared to the verb knowledge of their hearing college-level peers and hearing second-language learners of English, whose English acquisition exhibits many parallels with deaf learners' acquisition. The findings of this research will also establish an empirical basis on which to develop more effective methods for teaching English to deaf students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant research involved a large-scale assessment of deaf and hard-of-hearing (DHH) college students’ knowledge of subtle English language properties previously unexplored or underexplored in this student population. As a consequence of severely restricted access to spoken-language input, DHH individuals across the educational spectrum understandably face serious challenges in developing English language skill levels sufficient for academic success. With wide variation, these challenges persist even at the college level, where strong English language and literacy skills are critical to managing the discourses of academic disciplines.

Because of the central role that verbs play in determining the structures and interpretations of entire sentences, the diverse phenomena explored in this research focused specifically on the properties of English verbs. Research participants’ knowledge of the following verb-determined properties and sentence types was assessed: (i) transitive, intransitive, passive, and middle sentences; (ii) semantic role options of sentence arguments (agent, instrument, theme, experiencer, etc.); (iii) sentences’ argument realization options (structural patterns) and alternations; (iv) linguistic event types conveyed by sentences (states, activities, accomplishments, achievements); (v) motion events? (vi) resultative and depictive phrases; (vii) general-purpose and academic English verbs.

Large sentence-acceptability rating scale tasks were constructed and employed to assess DHH college students’ relative knowledge of the targeted properties. In addition to a comparison group of hearing native speakers (NS) of English, the tasks were also administered to hearing adult students of English as a Second Language (L2). The inclusion of L2 English learners as a comparison group was motivated by existing research that has uncovered parallels between college-level L2 English learners and DHH students in the acquisition of certain English language properties. One goal of the present grant research was to further explore and explain other acquisitional parallels that might emerge in the assessments of the broad range of targeted English properties. The research also explored the possible influences of overall English language proficiency on relative knowledge of the targeted properties. The DHH students and the L2 English students (the “learner groups”) were each clustered into three distinct levels of assessed overall English proficiency.

Hypothesized higher performance by the NS group than the two learner groups on most assessed properties was confirmed. Hypothesized parallels between the two learner groups in their knowledge of most of the targeted English properties were also attested. Within each targeted domain, these parallels were explained on the basis of theory-driven relative degrees of derivational complexity distinguishing specific clusters of properties: greater knowledge of derivationally less complex structures and lesser knowledge of derivationally more complex structures. Relative derivational complexity was shown to influence the two learner groups similarly, resulting in the emergence of acquisitional parallels in the newly targeted English domains. Hypothesized proficiency level effects—increasing knowledge of targeted properties with increasing overall English proficiency—were also confirmed. With respect to knowledge of specific English verb meanings, participants’ knowledge of general-purpose and academic English verbs was assessed on the basis of corpus-determined relative lexical frequency ranges. Those assessments confirmed the hypothesized influence of lexical frequency on verb acquisition. Knowledge of targeted verbs increased as their corpus-determined frequency ranges increased. Accordingly, relative derivational complexity, lexical frequency, and overall English language proficiency were shown to underlie DHH and L2 English learners’ acquisitional parallels.

The results of this grant research have contributed a wealth of new insight into English language acquisition of discrete English language properties by DHH students. The results have shown that the English language characteristics and outcomes of DHH learners are not uniquely tied to the consequences of deafness on the acquisition of spoken languages such as English. The extensive parallels that this research uncovered between DHH and L2 English learners were explained on the basis of theoretically principled mechanisms underlying linguistic knowledge across populations, parallels observable at least by the college level.

Over the course of the grant, 900 research participants were assessed on their knowledge of the diverse targeted properties. The grant research has contributed to the investigation of unexplored areas of DHH students’ knowledge of both fundamental and subtle verb-driven English properties within specific linguistic and lexical domains. In doing so, it has provided theory-grounded unifying explanations tied to independently motivated linguistic constructs. Accordingly, the results provide principled new guidance for the development of more fine-grained assessments of DHH students’ (and hearing L2 students’) English language knowledge, as well as new insights for the development of focused, principled English teaching curricula, methods, and materials. The results also provide a realistic assessment of the extent to which DHH college students’ vocabulary knowledge may not be sufficiently robust for successfully managing academic English discourse.
